posts.cooked:
Hello! I have a command, and within that command I have a variable that I want to keep the same across all the usage of said command. To do this, I need the same instance of the command to be used across all of the keybinds. However, I can‚Äôt figure out how to do this because the command constructor has a String that has to be inputted. How can I use the same command instance with different string inputs so that I am able to keep the variable?

Slight example: (ShoulderTeleop.java) (RobotContainer.java)

How it is currently: I don‚Äôt want it like the current version because it will cause the variable to have two different instances which will interfere with my code.

For example:

I have a variable called A in command. A is equal to 20.

When the DOWN button is pressed, it runs the command which changes A to 10. However, when UP is pressed, the command SHOULD change A to 20 but instead it would be 30 because both buttons have created a new instance of command

If you need to pass different parameters, then by definition you need different command instances. Why do you need a shared mutable variable? A static (shared between all instances of a class) variable would work for that, but this design/structure sounds questionable.
Hello! Static variable worked! Thanks. Honestly, we‚Äôre just doing some testing and this sounds like the best solution for our ideas.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Starlight220:

Why do you need a shared mutable variable? ‚Ä¶ but this design/structure sounds questionable.

Yeah, depending on what this variable is, it sounds like it should probably be tracked in the Subsystem itself and accessed/changed by the Command(s).
This sounds interesting. Could you elaborate on tracking it through the subsystem?

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm glad you got it, but I‚Äôm gonna give a hypothetical of how I would tackle something like this, just for anyone else who may stumble through this thread!

So I don‚Äôt know exactly what this variable you are using is, but I‚Äôm gonna take a guess that its the position for an arm? Perhaps the input you‚Äôre passing to a PID Controller in your Shoulder subsystem or something along that line.

First I‚Äôd setup the Subsystem to track this position in a variable (3468 absolutely does this when we use the SparkMax PID Controller as there is no way to get the last setpoint/reference back out once you set it‚Ä¶). Then, add some methods to be able to read and manipulate this setpoint. I‚Äôm not gonna specify anything explicit about what PID Controller Class or config I‚Äôm using, just to keep this vauge as it would work generally for a WPILib PIDController object or  PID Subsystem, or the PID Object from either CTRE or REV for their respective Motor Controllers.

Now, we can have our commands use this! In your example, I am going to assume that your ‚ÄúManual‚Äù strings modified the position by some amount (added/subtracted Y from the current position setpoint) and that ‚ÄúLow‚Äù and the corresponding Medium/High/Intake/Shelf/whatever were setting explicit preset positions to go to. For this, I‚Äôd create to commands.

ShoulderSetPosition - where you pass in an exact position to go to

ShoulderAdjustPosition - where you pass in a delta to apply to the position

These would look a little something like:

Finally, you should be able to use these commands in your RobotContainer without worrying about your position going out of sync.

Now just to clear up anything about my approach to using Constants.ShoulderConstants all over the place, I would normally import the Constants class and then just use ShoulderConstants.k<variable> to make it shorter, but left it explicit in all uses here. I‚Äôd have these values setup in the Constants class like so:

Also, even though I am passing constants here, the reason I used DoubleSupplier s in my commands is so I have the flexibility to re-use the same commands if for instance I write a method that uses a sensor (like a camera) or something to figure out the setpoint dynamically I would use that as the input (though this is probably more common for Velocity PID Controllers in a Shooter subsystem with a flywheel than a Position subsystem though I still use this convention for consistency in my code design so you always know ‚Äúsetpoint input is going to be a DoubleSupplier‚Äù regardless), or if I used a joystick axis as the delta. Some examples:
Hey! Thanks for this example. It helped me figure out a flaw within the code I wrote!

data.fancy_title: Need help with using a command without making a new instance of that command
data.title: Need help with using a command without making a new instance of that command

accepted_answer.excerpt:
If you need to pass different parameters, then by definition you need different command instances. 
Why do you need a shared mutable variable? A static (shared between all instances of a class) variable would work for that, but this design/structure sounds questionable.
